title: another 8 week wait!
body:
I'm honestly shocked!

I've tried to rearrange a nurses appointment(scheduled in 2 weeks) - to be offered one in 8 weeks! Lets hope I have nothing serious wrong because this surgery isn't likely to offer any help!

I recently had knee surgery and trying to get an appointment to get stitches removed was a joke itself ( it was supposed to be 1 week after the operation and I had to wait over 10 days)
when I spoke to the nurse about it directly she was shocked and said she would always prioritise time sensitive procedures such as this; and now this!!

Why if you cannot meet the needs of the patients you have registered are you accepting new patients?

author: np67
title: Unprofessional
body: When I was in East Surrey I experienced two nurses who I felt were nasty and unprofessional. I was sent home without treatment, only to be sent back almost straight away. I would never want to go there again... call themselves caring, to me that's a joke.

readBy.name: Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust

author: Dozymare
title: Came to minor injuries after a suspected broken/fractured ankle
body:
So came to Minor Injuries which I had an appointment for and had been referred by the western whom had done a video call to review my injury during the covid pandemic. Every single member of staff that dealt with me were absolutely lovely and so helpful and caring.  
I was in and out in 35 minutes! I had an X Ray, so was expecting it to take longer. Couple of hours anyway.  
The only negative thing that I have to say about my visit was dealing with the reception, one staff member I felt was just horribly rude, blunt, lacked any kind of people skills which you 100% need when working in a hospital dealing with people that are not well or in pain. The staff member spoke to me so badly, I stopped myself bringing up how disgusting I found their attitude to be, because I didn’t think it would make any difference. I was actually shocked, myself who also works in the health sector... their were no words.  
All the nurses and the staff member that conducted my X Ray, to the staff member leading me out I couldn’t fault any of them.

author: Curdy
title: Very concerned
body:
I have returned to ward 17 as I have been an inpatient previously and got professional care but on this occasion it has taken one bad apple in the staff to make me feel very concerned the level of care and professionalism within their team.  
I felt I was spoken down to like a child and I was refused assistance from the staff member in question with a very bad attitude and a heavy chip on their shoulder making personal comments and claiming that they "know what I am capable of" as they knew all about me in my notes - bearing mind this was the first time I ever seen this member of staff and not even gave me the courtesy of saying their name when they introduced themselves.  
I have since written a letter of complaint - please understand this was one bad experience and the majority of staff would do everything to help or assist anyone.

author: HC303
title: Neurology referral
body: My 1 year old son had a referral to neurology after having some "funny turns". I was asked to email videos of these. This afternoon I had a phone call from an epilepsy nurse. I was advised I had already spoken to the doctor and had been googling. I corrected the nurse as this was incorrect information, I have not spoken to this doctor nor have I been googling. The nurse said the doctor had advised at my son's review he had spoken to me. I am concerned information has been fabricated or may have been mixed up with another patient's information. She also discussed my son having "an unusual laugh" in one of the videos and said I had been concerned about this. This information is completely incorrect and has never been mentioned previously. This afternoon I have had to request a copy of my son's medical notes to ensure it doesn't contain incorrect information. I would like to speak to someone to discuss this further, I would not like another parent to experience this and I have concerns about the wrong information being communicated.

title: Excellent Practice and Staff
body: Visited for a mysterious rash and the service I experienced was first class! Immense concern shown by the GP who ensured I was seen at Ambulatory Care within an hour. I am a Practice Manager in the NHS and would be very happy with the staff response. May thanks!

readBy.name: South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust

title: Good advice
body: Have been waiting for a cataract operation and wanted to know what was happening with those operations at the moment. Got through on the phone to a very helpful receptionist, who explained that those operations had been suspended until further notice. Bad news, but it was communicated in a good way.

title: Breast clinic
body:
After a fortnight of worry. The staff at Grindon Lane Breast Clinic really made me feel at ease

The staff were very professional, empathic and caring. The hygiene was evident and I felt at ease. My appointment was on time and efficient. 
Fantastic Service. 
Well Done.

title: Great practice
body: Would like to thank the lovely nurse I saw. She was very kind , friendly and helpful. Very caring . Took time to treat u with respect not like some that yr just another patient .

author: LauraMP
title: Amazing team
body:
It has been just over two weeks now since I gave birth to my little baby girl at Raigmore Maternity Unit. I have to say once again the care I received over my two days on Ward 9A and when in the Labour Suite was outstanding.  
On the Ward I was looked after by Krystel, Jen, Dani, Kelly, Carolyn and May. I cannot thank these ladies enough for everything these did for me before and after birth.  
I felt so well cared for every step of the way.  
Krystel had cared for me with my first birth and it was so lovely to recognise her straight away and have her look after me so well once again.  
When I moved to the labour suite Caitlyn did a fantastic job making me feel so relaxed and at ease ready for birth with the help of Fiona and Mairead.  
I feel so lucky to have such a wonderful Maternity hospital here in the Highlands and for the wonderful NHS care I have now received when giving birth to my little boy and now to my baby girl. The staff at Raigmore are what makes the hospital so special. ❤️ Thank you for everything.

title: Super Practice
body: Since the new GP has come, this practice has excelled. She is a delight and genuine cares for her patients. I'm so glad the registrations opened and not regretting leaving the other surgery down the road. I also get text reminders so they keep you well aware of my care. Super!!

author: Mrsslcp
title: Diagnosed with PTSD following the birth of my daughter
body:
When I first started my session I was very pessimistic. I felt that no one could ever get me out of the dark hole I was in.  
My daughter and I both nearly lost our lives and I went blind for several months! Not only that I also worked in the place this all happened!  
I came to Chrissie feeling hopeless and alone. My marriage was struggling my work life was struggling and I was in constant fear of everything little emotion I could possibly feel.  
Chrissie was patient and kind and has given me the tools and advice I needed to make changes to free myself and I will be forever grateful

author: Let down and shocked
title: My mother
body:
I feel that my mother was treated appallingly whilst in ward 10 and diagnosed with terminal cancer.  
On more than one occasion she was ignored and left sat in her own urine and came home with a cat 2 pressure sore after 5 nights and died not long after.  
Ironically she had been a carer most of her life and was let down by the professionals when she needed them the most.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Awful Telepone service
body: I dread making calls to reception by telephone, phone constantly rings, and they deny picking up and hanging up the phone just as they answer, leading to yet another lengthy wait, so usually have to go there to make an appointment to then they tell me to phone in,,, maybe they’ve taken on too many patients? And can’t cope? I’ve had this experience for a few years with them, and sure I’m not on my own, so frustrating always when I have to make appointment for medicine review.

title: Staff was very  helpful
body: I went into  the practice to collect my Prescription and Sick Note. The Staff on duty were very helpful and polite. Dealt with my further queries professionally.

author: Nicha
title: Anxiety
body: I had a rouge up bringing as a child. Most days I would not go outside thinking about what if? Then two years ago I lost my dad and life was to be so different again. My anxiety got really bad. But I come through it. But then this April I lost my sister. And then I started my telephone therapy and over the last three weeks. I feel like a different woman I look at life in a different way. And I might my anxiety better now. Thank you inclusion.

title: Disappointed
body: I haven’t been out since March but I was extremely disappointed when I visited the centre to have my feet checked. I was offered a mask but there was no hand gel in sight. I was promised on the phone there would be. I would have thought it would be available as it is a medical practice.

readBy.name: The Dudley Group NHS Foundation Trust

author: Wayne1
title: Disability of a child
body: We have had a lot of difficulties and challenges with our oldest and Diane helped alot with.

author: wp20
title: Seeking advice during covid 19
body:
I have been trying to contact the Hereford rheumatology support helpline for advice on increased pain in my joints. I am already a patient on oral methotrexate awaiting to be stepped up to injection therapy. Unfortunately due to the covid 19 situation being stepped up to the injections would not be safe as it could cause me to drop my blood levels further leaving me extremely vulnerable to any infection.  
I have obtained some over the counter remedies and need to check if the product is safe to take along side my other daily medications. I have spent 4 days trying to get through to the helpline, there is only a one hour window each day that you can try and speak to someone for advice. Their recorded message when you do manage to get through gives an email address for Hereford NHS. Frustrating for me, this email address is also failing. I'm getting to the point where I'm just going to give up.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Scubaman
title: PTSD
body:
I have had a few too many incidents happen to me in my life span (I am 24 years old).  
I have been in two High-Jacking situations and that is just two of my situations that I have had to deal with. Both high-jackings I was in, had occurred before I reach the age of 15.When I was told that I had PTSD is did not want to believe what I was being told, but as I went through the EMDR sessions with Rashmeet, I was shown how to displace the feeling/fears I had about every day struggles.  
I have now finished my sessions and I feel as if I am able to let the little things in life make me stronger and better for the up and coming years of my adult hood.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Larst55
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Community Therapy Team
body:
Due to Covid a lot of questions were asked on the phone, but as i needed a walking frame (i was using my husbands frame) the team came to my door and were able to look at the type/size of frame i needed without having to come in the house. The frame arrived very quickly and as it is smaller than the one i was using it has made a big difference and is much easier for me.  
Very happy with the service provided to me.

author: Zakia
title: Thank You
body: Thank You for support , blood transfusion 8/9 July and saving my life.

author: Myamazun
title: Endoscopy unit
body:
Arrived Wednesday the 15th for my Endoscopy procedure - having a tube put down my throat to look at my stomach.  
The staff on hand that dealt with me were professional and reassuring and they had me in and the procedure completed with care and encouragement.  
I volunteered for the throat spray so was able to leave shortly after the event.  
To the three Ladies who were there to carry out the procedure - Thank you and Keep up the great work.

author: colpot54
title: Covid test
body: Had test by lovely staff in Friday results phoned through today by a lovely staff nurse all clear: -) so my Cardioversion tomorrow can go ahead. Thank you all

author: Deborah08
title: Test results
body:
Called for test results.  
I felt nervous initially before receiving my results. But I was put at ease. There was a set of results that was not displayed and the staff member messaged the Drs directly for the results and called me back promptly. Much appreciated.

author: HW91
title: A consistent place of support
body:
I have recently completed the IRP course with Inclusion. Due to the COVID restrictions these took place online via video calls with Alex and Helen.  
Having attended groups in-person with inclusions I was apprehensive at how helpful online group meetings would be. I’m happy to say I could not have been more wrong!  
Alex and Helen were amazing at making everyone feel at ease and created what felt like a very safe, open and honest environment. Throughout the weeks, the course didn’t feel rigid and was like having a conversation. Alex and Helen kept us to topic by questioning certain view-points and asking for further clarification and I felt as though rather than give you the answers we all managed to come to them ourselves with their guidance. It has been so reassuring to have this Tuesday meeting during lockdown and I cannot thank Alex and Helen enough!  
Inclusions as a whole has been a consistent place of support for me during lockdown and everyone has gone above and beyond to continue service as normal as humanly possible and this has been invaluable and is very, very appreciated!

author: maganharde
title: General care
body: a few weeks ago I was taken to the tun-wells hospital more dead than alive and not much caring one way or the other, after test after test it was decided to operate but the outlook was pretty uncertain, however I made it through the operation, but what come next has changed me forever, the love and care I was shown brought me to tears, nothing was to much trouble, I want to say thank you to everyone involved in my care the trouble is peaple say thankyou a hundred times a day so it just doesent seem enough when somone has saved your life

author: Loch82
title: Labour and Delivery
body:
I have already left a review on the birth of my son, where the midwives were exceptional.  
My daughter was born in September where I arrived in a bit of a hurry to the community midwife centre, as my baby girl was born 15 minutes later.  
The two midwives handled the situation with absolute experience and confidence. I left with 0 stitches after a natural labour.  
I am confident in the experience of midwives at Paisley to cope with any birth that a future mother will experience! Can't fault them at all!

author: caringsk68
title: Visit to cardiac dept
body: Had to attend for a CT scan and needed to fast before the proceedure. The staff were so very welcoming (name checking for Prakesh and Raoul) Expalined everything very well and even gave me a cup of coffee and biscuit as soon as possible so I wasn't hungry or thirsty! The guys in the CT dept were also very welcoming and explained the proceedure well. Dr Saha was his usual charming self and that rounded off a great visit. East Surrey have really improved their patient care over the last few years making it a really great hospital to visit, very impressive progress!!

readBy.name: Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust

author: Cagann
title: Excellent care
body: I was taken to A&E with breathing difficulty and then onto Clayton ward for 9 days the care I was given was excellent. Each and every member of the NHS are amazing thankyou all so much

title: Great customer Service
body: I had an issue with my health and phoned the surgery. the reception staff couldn't have been more helpful. They made me feel relaxed and at ease and nothing was too much for them. i would recommend this surgery to anyone. thank you.

title: Made me feel embarrassed
body:
The person who treated me acted as if they couldn't be bothered. I was following advice from my GP, due to an ongoing problem. The staff member then told me that it was for accidents and emergencies and mine was neither and I was to go back to my GP. This person then came into A&E and in front of everyone announced my problem out loud - so much for privacy and confidentiality. They were plain rude and in my opinion had absolutely no people skills.  
This made me feel embarrassed and quite upset as well as a little angry as this attitude was not brilliant at all, I knew what the problem was, I was just following advice from my GP as it could have been something very serious! I feel like I’m back at stage one now and still feeling ill nearly a month after this started!

author: HappyB
title: Operation on gall bladder
body: Absolutely fantastic  surgeons doctors nurses and all very pleasant and helpful

title: Knowledgeable doctors working hard during tough…
body: I submitted an online consult via their website last night for a non urgent problem which required review and a prescription. Within less than 24 hours I have been issued a prescription and sent a text letting me know. These are unprecedented times for the health service and Kenmore are working hard to keep up services for all. Knowledgable doctors and nurses, helpful receptionists. Thank you!!

title: Great help from surgery
body: I’d like to thank the receptionist and doctor who were very kind in helping me get the prompt and efficient medical help I needed over the phone and online. They were so good and  without them I would never have gone to the hospital when I did for the treatment I needed. Thank you so much. I’m really pleased you’re my surgery.

author: junesr75
title: I feel this is not OK at all
body: I visited RCHT in June 2020 for an overdose. I feel that the treatment I had was disgusting. I could overhear the nurses laughing that I had overdosed and I had a severe tremor and once it had stopped the nurse said “thank f*** for that” I then turned onto my side to try and get to sleep and I heard a staff member's voice saying “I do not want to see your arse thank you”. I could not say anything as I was on my own. Another staff member made a reference to a sex doll. I think this is absolutely despicable. As someone in the health profession, I feel this is not ok at all.

author: blueqc93
title: Over the phone CBT sessions.
body:
During lockdown as I had already started my CBT sessions with a very knowledgeable and empathetic lady called 'Mame', I was given the option to continue my sessions over the phone, which I was initially very nervous about, because I felt my hearing was a bit below par and wasn't sure how I would cope. Or to continue to do sessions online with the option to contact someone as and when for help with it.  
After my first phone call with Mame I realised that was the best way forward for me. I found her knowledgeable, empathetic, completely in tune with how I needed her to be to help me move forward.  
She asked what I was hoping to gain from the treatment and what outcome I was hoping for. She explained that CBT was not about making you look at things more positively, but to help enable you to respond differently to situations and therefore enable a different outcome.  
The whole way through each week I completed a questionnaire to monitor my mood and ability to cope according to my mood before each session.  
She listened to everything I had to say and once treatment had started she would praise me if I was on the 'new way' of thinking or would very emphatically but also very professionally give me examples of how I wasn't quite there yet. ( My description, not hers)  
Her guidance, patience, empathy and knowledge were a complete breath of fresh air. She taught me the difference between An Aggressive, Passive (me) and Assertive approach and I learnt that for me, Assertive was definitely the way forward. And how to do it effectively.  
I was sent lots of information, by email and did homework during sessions to help practice my outcome.  
At the end of my sessions of approximately 16 weeks. Mame expained the difference between my scores for mood. I had come down from a high of 21/22 to 2/22.  
I still have a long way to go as it has taken 60 years to get to where I am. But at present I feel that I have the tools to move forward. If, somewhere down the line I feel a big slip of not managing, I would definitely get in touch with Inclusion Thurrock again as I found my experience a very positive one from beginning to end I was also told that I would be welcome to do so.  
Thank you for all your help. And thank you especially Mame. A wonderful lady.

author: 123thenewme
title: Suffering with depression and anxiety
body:
This story is about depression and anxiety - but more importantly, how I overcame it with help! If I’m honest I had been suffering with depression and anxiety longer than I have ever admitted to.  
After losing 2 key people in my life I lost a 3rd. My nan and my aunt and uncle who had cared for me when I was younger and my dad was fighting for his life and needed my mum more than I did, at that time anyway.  
My nan loved me unconditionally, I was her world and when she passed away my world came crashing down around me. Who would love me unconditionally? Who would be my go to person? More importantly, who wouldn’t judge me for being ‘silly’? Through that time my aunt became my go to person, sadly she developed Alzheimer’s and would ask me, ‘I love you don’t I’ as quickly as she developed Alzheimer’s she was gone! 2 down I began to become anxious about leaving home, I lost all my confidence and had begun to feel worthless, not suicidal but with thoughts of how people would be better off without me. Having a young family and being married didn’t ear those dark times and thoughts. If anything they fueled them. I began to spend money like it was going out of fashion, the inexpensive crap I bought made me feel better if only for a short while, so I bought more. Had to take out payday loan after payday loan to keep up with just the basic of bills. I all the while keeping it a secret about how I felt and how I was losing control. I felt I was at rock bottom. How wrong could I be...  
My uncle became ill and passed away quickly, my mum had a stroke all the while I kept working, looking after my dad and my family. Not telling anyone what was still going on deep inside. Right then was the 2 occasions I thought of ending it all! Had it planned but for whatever reason, I didn’t do it. I just saw this as something else I had failed at! Go me! This was at rock bottom as I had been.  
There was only one person who really knew and it wasn’t because I told her, but because she knew me. My oldest friend called me out on it. She never commented about how stupid I was or what a failure I was or why hadn’t I done any housework or showered and washed my hair. Instead it was, ‘right what are we going to do about it.’ Partial relief, momentarily actually because although she had called me out on it burying the head in the sand technique I pushed all her hard work and advice to one side.  
One day about a year ago, talking with my mother in law she was commenting on how people get so low they commit suicide and she just didn’t understand it. It was then I told her, it’s easy! The plan, the need the desire to end the heartbreaking demoralizing car crash that had become my life. It all came out everything. I went to the GP who upped my antidepressants and I completed the safeguarding questionnaire. The results of that meant he referred me to inclusion Thurrock.  
To be honest I’d forgotten about it. When I got a call offering me a group session. Not what I needed or wanted so turned it down. The world went into lockdown, my answer no phones ringing no knocks at the door and limited post through my letterbox meant I could do the bury my head routine again. Then my miracle happened. I got a call offering a virtual 1:1. Also My friend who called me out on it lent me money to clear my debts with an affordable repayment - but Jade from inclusion Thurrock became my beginning of the end. The first day I spoke with Jade I hadn’t showered or been worried about my personal hygiene for nearly 2 weeks. This was as low as I had ever been. Our first meeting I thought yeah right like she is gonna be able to help. I even thought that on the second session. But... the 3rd session was where it began to change, not overnight but going in the right direction. Jade was no fool she knew exactly how I was playing the game and she held me accountable, not in a bad way but just gave me a scenario of changing one word. I kept using the word selfish, over a couple of weeks she had me using more positive words like self care. She gave me homework which was more like targets of what I needed to do that week, walk, make notes, plan ahead but they gave me focus on something different. I began seeing things very differently. I’m not going to lie and say it was a walk in the park because to admit wrong doings, dark thoughts etc made me especially evaluate what I already knew - life ain’t easy! The weekly questionnaires not only gave Jade the feedback she needed to know the direction of the plan, but it gave me time to evaluate how I was truly feeling. Rather than just ticking the I feel crap box I begun to question - do I feel crap though.  
The long and short of it this service saved me, not necessarily from suicide but from living a life of feeling worthless and unloved.  
I was told by a colleague this week Smiffy has her spunk back and yes I do the future doesn’t frighten me anymore because I have the strategies in my mind map and know how to cross each hurdle I’m not looking at life through rose tinted spectacles life’s rollercoasters are still going to come along it’s how I deal with them that will prevent me relapsing back into old trails of thoughts but allowing myself an occasional lapse just means I’ve finally got it sorted.  
I can’t thank Jade enough, her commitment to me while we met all be it virtually showed me I could do it. When she asked if I was ready for this to be the last session I paused. I waited to see if the sinking feeling came back. Jade noticed this and asked why I paused I explained and she said well what did you notice. I noticed no sinking feeling and knew there would never be a better opportunity to take the leap of faith. I’m now enrolled in an access to higher education diploma, I’m exercising and feel good.  
I know I’ve gone on but it’s important to hear why I needed help and how the help came.  
Tiny steps win the race and inclusion Thurrock became the end of my old ways of thought and the beginning of the new.  
#corny but what’s life without a bit of drama.

author: mum of vulnerable 10 year old
title: Frustration under Covid restrictions ease - letting our vulnerable kids down
body:
My 10 year old Daughter was seeing a counsellor from CAMHS at the Hamilton base, who was absolutely fantastic and gained my daughters trust fairly quickly and we felt as though we were making good progress...…. then obviously Covid struck and kids were dismissed and discharged in a video call which was very emotional for all concerned.  
I was sent some links from our counsellor in order to help try and deal with this at home …. When contacting one of the links I was told that they did not deal with individual cases of support and I would have to go back to GP etc, this was very frustrating.  
My daughters mental health and anxiety has escalated considerably during Covid, has affected her eating, sleeping, severe moods, to the point where she would not even do her schoolwork, go out on bike, get out her bed or eat somedays.  
I contacted the school, prior to closure as I was told they could be a source of support and got nothing back.  
I Myself suffer from anxiety and depression and I could see the signs excalate very quickly, I contacted my local GP, who was fab and said she definately needed to be referred back to the Camhs team again. This process was fab and very officiant I am pleased to say and before I knew it my original contact was back on the phone to try and help us out...... with a video call.  
This however was a bit of a disaster, between links not working and being lost several times, to the fact that it has been 5 months since my daughter had seen the member of staff, who she adored, so she was obviously very nervous, worried and completely out of her comfort zone and therefore a total closed book. We are of course going to try a few phone calls between them both to try and open up the trust again, but I find it absolutely ludicrous, frustrating and angry that the NHS are advising that the Camhs team may not start again until November, my daughter is 10 years old, who does not have to socially distance from other kids under 12, she will be going back to school full time in Aug, where she will be socially distancing from her teacher, she can go to football coaching and distance herself from her coach, why NHS can she not be allowed in a room with her counsellor at 2m safe distance in order to protect and help her mental health and anxiety. This definately needs reviewing as it is letting our vulnerable children down.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)
North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

links.id: service updated to meet restrictions lifted

author: Vonne
title: Excruciating pain caused by nerve damage
body:
I rarely visit the practice and can usually manage my own health issues. This time it was different! Unable to actually go to the surgery due to the pandemic, I nevertheless received excellent service from both the receptionists and the GPS via the phone.  
The GPS were empathetic, whilst recognising that there was little they could do for me apart from prescribe pain relief. They did this, helpfully making suggestions and adjustments. I couldn’t have faced each pain ridden day without their help! In all, an excellent service was provided despite the restrictions of lockdown.  
My sincere thanks to all.

title: Professional surgery
body: I attended for an appointment with the nurse. There were lots of safety precautions in place in response to the pandemic and the service was as prompt, friendly and professional as ever.

title: Good Nursing
body:
I received a very courteous and apologetic telephone call before 8 am informing me that the nurse I was due to see at 8.45am had rung in to say she was sick.  Could I come later. all was ok and the receptionist could not have been more pleasant or accommodating.
the nurse who was obviously under more pressure than usual was kind enough to do my obs and also test a urine sample for me neither of which had been scheduled but because of my circumstances and covid she kindly did. She was charming and reassuring despite her timetable.

title: Nurses are nice, aftercare not great
body:
I opted for a medical abortion at 7 weeks due to personal reasons. I was originally told on the phone that i was 10 weeks almost 11 so a surgical would be my only option. However, when arriving at the centre and had a scan i was only 7 weeks so opted for the medical as i thought it would be less invasive. The options werent really explained to me at this point but if they had been i would have chosen the surgical. The excruciating pain i went through was horrendous. In the booklet it states the pain can last from 4-6 hours. My did but the pain remained for almost a week after! So much so i thought a trip to a&e was needed. There is no aftercare whatsoever, they do not call you to see how you are or if everything went ok. Its a case of there are the tablets, take them and go home to rest! 
There should be a clear understanding of what to expect if you choose the medical or surgical, everything should be explained to you in detail in order for you to make the right choice and as pain and stress free as possible

title: Great service
body: Thank you seems such an ordinary word but I want to say thank you to all the staff I met during my recent visit to A and E and then my admittance to KGH. Everyone I met worked with both a high amount of professionalism and care. They put my mind at rest and really looked after me.

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Fantastic practice
body: Always fantastic service realy freindly staff and nothing is to much trouble they look after you to the best of there abilitie would highly recommend this practice to anyone over all the best practice to be with they care .

title: Good so far
body: I understand that phone lines are busy but I pressed 5 requesting a call back so your excuse really doesn't hold water.  As soon as the line clears you should ring back.  Or are you saying that the phone service call back service isn't worth the effort.

title: telephone
body: completely useless.my wife and myself where ringing for a telephone appointment  to hear test results of our blood tests.I rang on Friday 17th at 4.30 only to be told  I can only ring at 2.00pm or 8.00 am, strange system? so I rang today Monday only to hear the corona virus statement yet again for 2 minutes then music and every 30 seconds I can book online(you can't) after waiting about 15 minutes I finally got through only to be told no more appointments today,fine I will have one tomorrow ,no I have to ring again tomorrow just on the off chance I might get through.considering the practice rang my wife to say her results were there its seems very strange we cant get an appointment tomorrow,I thought that is what computers are for.why cant I book an appointment for tomorrow???

title: Never Answer The Phone!
body: This GP surgery never answer the phone, it rings and rings with no answer or option to leave a voicemail! I have been trying to get through for several days now. I would not recommend this GP surgery there’s some severe admin problems.

title: Fantastic patient care
body: I was admitted on the 15/7 to the Day surgery unit Leverhulme. I was in for a planned surgical procedure I was extremely anxious from the nursing staff to the consultant and Anesthesiologist theatre recovery nurses health carers and porters/cleaners/admin, each one of you are a credit to the NHS made me feel welcome and safe and could tell I was anxious. The care I received was exceptional and I was safely discharged in the same day now  recovering well. Thank you all for the kind compassionate care I received.  I would highly recommend you.

readBy.name: Wirral University Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Reception needs work
body: Very brusk reception almost rude on nearly all occasions. Getting an appointment is like pulling teeth. Even when the doctor says, on the phone, if things don't clear up you need a face to face you still can't get one. Ling house has stopped being a surgery and become a covid crisis centre, and not a very good one.

title: Good service
body:
Had to attend A&E and was pleased with my treatment and all the staff I came in contact with 
The lady at receptionist was very nice as was the nurse practitioner.
Could not fault anything

title: Impossible to get an appointment
body: I rang a week or so ago as I am having severe shoulder pain. A few days later a physiotherapist rang me and then emailed me a link to some shoulder exercises he thought might help. My shoulder has got worse and I am waking up every night in great pain. I have tried to make an appointment but am told I am 22nd in the queue not once but 3 times. A bit of a coincidence that I am always 22nd isn't it. Do Lister Medical Centre really expect people to wait for over an hour to be put through? or do they just want people to give up and leave them in peace? I am in great pain and will have to go to A & E if this goes on as that's the only way it seems I can get any  help.

title: Great Care
body: I was admitted to A&E with internal bleeding. The care I received was exceptional from all the nurses and doctors. I was then transferred to Ward A1 where I also received exceptional care. Thank you to everyone especially at these hard times. You are all angels.

title: Great Care
body: Excellent service, care, professionalism from all in the plastics department. It was also friendly with 2 staff members outside this dept. advising us of the way to go. Having never been in this hospital before I had no idea where I was going.

title: Patience and understanding
body: I came as a day case today to have an EBUS from the minute I walked in every member of staff was pleasant and helpful. I was extremely nervous about the procedure but the consultant was patient understanding, and made me feel confident to go ahead. Needless to say the procedure was not half as awful as I thought and the recovery staff were lovely!Thank you

title: Outstanding
body:
I'm not a fan of blood tests at the best of times as have had unfortunate experiences elsewhere. The nurse who took my blood samples at Caythorpe was outstanding. Quick, reassuring, virtually painless, very chatty & upbeat.

Well done & thank you.

title: Fantastic service
body:
I attended the minor injuries department today 20/7 for treatment to my injured finger caused by a circular saw . From the time I got to the reception and booking area to being treated was only fifteen minutes at the most . The checking system was very quick and efficient and the treatment by the friendly nurse was excellent. I didn’t think I should attend today but was persuaded to by my wife , you have many more serious patients to deal with than my cut 
finger . Thank you very much .

title: caring hospital
body:
received excellent care staff very attentive all needs catered for 
thoroughly recommend them food very good kept clean at all times lovely rooms with country side views

title: Great surgery a new beginning
body: It seems that hornsey park surgery has a new beginning. They are under new management and suddenly i am getting my medication instantly. They are replying to my emails and now picking up the phone when you call them. Really happy with the doctor. They listen to you and actually listen. Thank you

title: Well looked after during pandemic
body: We are at an unusual times. I contracted the corona virus and was suffering from it for three weeks. I had a severe case of the virus but did not require hospitalisation. I contacted the practice from my second week of suffering from the virus to ask for help and advise on available medication. Since then, I have been regularly checked by one of the doctors from the practice. The checks were at regular intervals until I have recovered from the virus.

title: Excellent and efficient care
body: Thank you for excellent care of my 11yr old son diagnosing and treating a broken wrist. No problems with parking, very clear. Fantastic staff and very professional considering covid distance requirements etc. X-ray was quick and whole process seamless. Thank you.

title: Great service
body: Great service in these troubled times nothing is too much trouble ,very caring and considerate could not ask for better service

title: Excellent , efficient , new member of staff
body:
I called the GP to arrange for a same day appointment , the lovely new member of staff was so polite , efficient , and great patient service from start to finish , i had to also collect my sample bottle and i met her and she was so brilliant at explaining  I was going to leave the surgery until i spoke to this new staff member and she had said to me i will try my very best to help you but if you have this problem again then you can make your choice . She made me feel to give this surgery a comment like this , need more staff hands on , and who have great talking manner 
Some members of staff need more training on talking . Im really hoping for the best with this surgery But things could be better with new staff

title: Simply amazing!
body: From the moment I walked in to this clinic I was treated with great respect, the TV screen and music really helped calm my nerves and anxiety about my injury.  I felt a few shivers up the spine from magnetic waves but I understand nothing can be done about that. This clinic deserves more recognition

title: Sent home and have no idea what my outcome is
body:
Firstly I would like to state I have worked in health and social care myself for over a decade, and I am very understanding that services are under pressure and human error does occur.

I was taken into the rapid assessment department in the early hours by ambulance after having a sudden and unbearable pain on my left side. I couldn't move or walk. I have had a problem with an ovarian cyst that I had operated on on the same side a few years ago and was absolutely certain this was what was happening.

I spoke at length about how I also suffer with mental health issues with the paramedics which include severe anxiety and CPTSD. One of them was incredible and couldn't help enough. The other so rude my partner even commented on this. 

Was wheeled in in a wheelchair and was banged into every wall on the way. It hurt even to sit and I was told to wait in a side room with two older men who were clearly suffering with issues with substances. As a young girl with mental health problems this really distressed me. Luckily I found the lovely paramedic who organised for me to be sat in a side room.

Had blood work done and was told I had high levels of potassium. Which with my medical experience I know is very serious. He asked to take more blood and I never saw him again. I was still sitting in a chair and after an hour sobbing with no one coming to see if I was ok asked a nurse if there was anywhere I could lie down as there were plenty of beds.

She very rudely told me to follow her. I asked if I could have some help and she told me not to be a baby and stormed off walking with me trying to walk still in tears.

I was then sat near the major resus unit, again in a chair, where all the staff seemed to be. I again sat crying my heart out in so much pain for another hour and no one came to my assistance. I was eventually approached by a dr who finally moved me to a bed.

I was given a mixture of pain meds and told that my pain was sciatica. Which I said I 100% did not believe as I knew the pain I was having from experience. He said he had never known a case of gynae problems causing this much pain that also affected my leg, gave me a prescription for diazepam and told me to leave.

I have no idea what my blood levels are like. No offer of any kind of scan. No follow up. Am lying in bed since coming home in floods of tears. Absolutely let down.

readBy.name: East Suffolk and North Essex NHS Foundation Trust

title: My visit to the hospital for a Colonoscopy
body:
I would like to say that the 
 wonderful treatment and care that I received in this department yesterday was second to none.
ALL of the staff were caring and very professional.

readBy.name: Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Phone line constantly engaged
body:
Having been advised to phone Monday 20th July to get an appointment to speak to the doctor who authorised a blood test, I tried for 40 minutes to contact the surgery. All I got was the engaged tone except for three occasions when the call seemed to connect only to be cut off after one ring. This seemed as if someone lifted the receiver and put it down again deliberately to cut off the call. I tried the phone line several times during the day but, again just got the engaged tone. On 20th July I had several phone calls in and out on my landline so I deduce that my telephone is not faulty. I tried the surgery number late in the day, as an experiment, and was immediately connected to a recorded message. This shows that the telephone number is working.
I have been unwell for the last several weeks but in the present virus situation and out of consideration for the overworked NHS, had kept attempted contact with the surgery to a minimum. 
At last, a couple of weeks ago, I was able to have a telephone conversation GP who was very helpful and organised a blood test. This GP told me at the time that the results may need to be followed up. 
When I enquired about my test results on Friday 17th July, I was told that a follow up was required, as previously advised by the GP, and that I should phone on the morning of Monday 20th July to book an appointment. 
This was hopeless due to the phone line being constantly engaged, as previously described.
On three occasions in the last four years (well before coronavirus) I have had to resort to paying for a consultation with a private doctor after being told that either GP's were too busy to see me, I could have an appointment two or three weeks in the future, or just being fobbed off with the excuse that no appointments were available. It is hardly surprising that I have little or no faith in the NHS. 
I am 75 years old, have been unwell for some weeks and now cannot access help from a medical professional due to the seeming inability of the surgery to have a working phone line.

title: Not good experiences
body:
I've been attending here for 20 months and never been too impressed but now they've got my blood test results mixed up, gave me the wrong results earlier and the receptionist was so abrasive about it when I rang to try and clear it up, that she couldn't get me off the phone quick enough and I'm still none the wiser about my blood test. 
I'm usually all for giving people the benefit of the doubt but there is no need for rudeness.

title: Excellent care and excellent communication with…
body:
My husband was admitted to Furness General Hospital on 25 March, 2020. He tested positive for Covid-19.  He was fully sedated and put on a ventilator.  After 3 weeks he was given a tracheostomy, which was removed after 2 weeks.  He spent 2 nights in CCU before being moved to Ward 7 for just over a week.  He completed his stay in Abbey View, for rehabilitation.  He returned home after 9 weeks in hospital.                                              The care he received saved his life and was compassionate and sensitive throughout.
I was unable to visit him in the early days but the communication from the staff, particularly from those in ICU, was always clear, honest but encouraging and reassuring.  They took time to answer my questions and did not rush me, although they must have been very busy and under pressure.
My husband has been at home for almost 8 weeks and is making slow, steady progress towards recovery, which we know will take months.  He was well-supported by physiotherapists and the occupational therapist to start with and the respiratory nurse is still working with him now, to help him get stronger, by walking a reasonable distance, with the help of some oxygen support.
We are so grateful to all the professionals, who have been involved in his care, rehabilitation and recovery. 
One piece of constructive feedback would be to suggest that when patients are being moved between wards, it would be helpful to give ample warning and an explanation of the next stage in the treatment.  When a fragile patient is feeling uncertain and vulnerable and has settled into a ward, a change of surroundings can be quite traumatic.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust

title: Good Service
body:
Thank you to the Receptionists for helping with queries and passing on information to the relevant place.
The recent telephone Asthma review I had was excellent, supportive and informative. Thank you.
Thank you for all being there during the Coronavirus.

author: laurac2201
title: Everything was very efficient
body: Miss Rao, Rachel and Janet were extremely friendly and made the experience as pain free as possible. We joked around which helped. I was in and out for my appointment and everything was very efficient. I did not feel in any danger at any time being in the hospital during covid 19.

author: li li
title: Left on our own
body:
l have COPD which is not good I'm 54 and this year I have been in hospital, with Carbon monoxide in my lungs and I could not breathe and had to go into ICU, on a c pac face mask. Left hospital and never had no help? Then fell downstairs and fracture my head in two places and lost my memory and my sister got rid of my dog and said I told her to, don't remember, I loved my dog I feeling a bit lost without her 💔 😢  
That was just before lockdown, me and my dad was left on our own. I didn't start to remember until middle of April but no one told anyone how it would be for me? Even now l feel lost and no one has told me anything, l only found out l broken my head in two places 3 weeks ago. So can someone please help?

readBy.name: Hull University Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Polly34
title: A coil being fitted
body: I arrived at the hospital for my appointment which was towards the end of lockdown so we were all wearing masks. Found the staff very friendly from the receptionist on main desk to the clerk on 1b and especially the nurses Amy and Val and a very be thank you to SR Palmer who put me at ease right from the start.

author: Rebhey
title: Great care
body:
I would like to thank Nurse Flavia and student nurse Ben on B3 and also a nurse that unfortunately I can’t remember the name of but I’m sure she will remember, she took me down to ct when I had a seizure.  
All 3 of them went above and beyond when I had multiple seizures on the ward which were new to me and absolutely terrifying , when I woke from them each time I was so scared but all 3 of them especially were fantastic at keeping me calm and I believe Flavia helped save my life after the first seizure when my heart rate escalated to over 220 and my blood pressure was almost inexistent.

author: Bonny 25
title: Spent 8 hours a day at this ward
body: My husband was transferred to ward 20 from ICU - I noticed patients shouting for help and seemingly ignored. My husband was forced to wear incontinence pads although he wasn’t and still isn’t incontinent, can only presume that is because they are not been answered when pressing for toilet assistance. Myself and family spent 8 hours a day at this ward to make sure his needs were met and he got his medication on time, would never allow him or anyone else in our family to be admitted to this ward again.

readBy.name: South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust

author: Mad-about-coffee
title: Physiotherapy
body: Feeling very reassured after my appointment with Kenny.   He was great at explaining things.   It not easy with all the PPE etc but he made my appointment fun, personalised and informative.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Emmrd63
title: IMCA Service
body:
Thank you for your IMCA support Cal.  
Very thorough and helpful, much appreciated.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Very Efficient.
body:
The front of office continues to excel with coordinating assistance.  Extremely courteous first contact (phone) - noticeable empathy.

Doctor's response - fast, effective and sincere.

Thank you.

author: Awb612
title: Minor operation
body: I would like to thank both David and Gerry at Stirling Community Hospital who carried out my procedure. They made me feel at ease and relaxed through out.   Very good explanation of the procedure and what will happen after.   Many thanks to both

title: Won't treat you and may lie/mislead
body:
I have a skin condition for 2 years. 
First I went two years ago, and a nurse saw me and said I shouldn't do anything as it will go away by itself.  1.5 years after it spread.
I went again this year. A nurse saw me again, not a doctor as I requested. Said the NHS don't provide treatment and tried to convince me not to book a doctor appointment. 
I finally managed to book a doctor appointment but this was only on the phone. First doctor said this can't be treated, but I pushed back and he sent me to a surgery. 
Luckily I was phoned by the surgery on my appointment date to say it was cancelled, as it seems I was booked to have the treatment on the date, but the type of treatment was not appropriate and not discussed with any doctor!!!
I called my GP again, and specifically asked to be referred to a certain clinic. He refused me twice saying he can't do it! I've checked with the clinic and it is. 

So they have lied to me a few times or just don't know or aren't bothered to look into helping me. 

Note this something similar happened on a few times before when they refused treatment for UTIs and severe flu, or for blood tests (e.g. they say NHS don't provide these, although I had them done at my prior GP...)
The one good thing is that they are booking phone calls with doctors more quickly now. I don't recall ever seeing one face-to-face though.

title: Disappointing service
body: G.p referral to insomnia clinic and sleep medicine. After 6-7 dates for Hugh's clinic being postponed or cancelled. I've been on sleeping pills for 47 years and cut down to 1 a night. I was desperate. told them to set an early date so my pill dose won't increase. I  sent an email. The date they sent me was for the end of |July 2021. I turned up there yesterday so grateful for a final appointment to be told the place was closed! This hospital in my experience has been drastically uncaring towards me. I told them I would never go back to be treated so cruelly. I didn't sleep at all last night as I was so upset about their refusal to listen to me and the shoddy lack of respect which I have received. I could never trust my life in their hands. It seems very unprofessional to me. In fact the only hospital which has ever maltreated me, sad to say.

title: Was great practise but now cant see a gp
body: I have been with the surgery for years and never could fault it.  However, now I've had an bad ear infection in both ears for 6 months. Saw a lovely nurse who took swabs and gave ear drops 4 months ago. My ears still the same and in alot of pain now. Called surgery to arrange dr appt as felt I needed reassurance from a dr and maybe a referral as am worried ear infections have spread behind ear drum.  Was shocked to be told drs wont see ear infections now and it's only nurses!!!! I said I'd had it for far too long and I need a dr to check them (more qualified) as I know ear infections if left spread to your bone and result in permanent hearing difficulties.  Was basically told only a nurse will see you, theres nothing.more they can do.  How can you leave a patient in pain, with muffled hearing and think it doesny need a dr to see me.  I got off the phone and cried at the coldness and how neglected if feel.  I truly dont know what to do now. How can drs just dismiss you like that. It's been 6 months and it's getting worse.  What is happening to our healthcare that people are being abandoned.

author: Pippa61
title: Series of upsetting events
body: After a string of different upsetting events in my life, I contacted the doctor for help. I was listened to and directed to some health care services, which I hadn't realised existed, I feel I have been given a lot of support and am in the process of learning how to deal with anxiety attacks. It's comforting to know there is help out there and I am feeling more hopeful for conquering my anxiety and leading a happier life, now. Thank you

author: ILLPATIENT
title: My mental state sunk to a low level
body:
I have had the misfortune to be an inpatient twice in this hospital, first time with a serious kidney stone, (I already had very poor kidneys) and the experience was not good. Many years later I was taken to Warwick hospital with bad chest pains. After an ECG showed that it was not a heart attack or clot, I was sent to a ward and ignored for a week, I was so bad I had not eaten a single mouthful for over 3 days, and drunk absolutely nothing, and had no sleep whatsoever for 86 hours, none of the staff seemed to notice or care, my mental state sunk to a staggeringly low level, I was told "to get over it " ... by a doctor. I was to have some additional tests ... never happened.  
My wife discharged me. One last terrible thing, patients soiling their beds because the nurses aids seemingly could not be bothered to attend to them. I am still not well, I believe that Warwick hospital damaged my mental health, which is showing very little improvement. What a shocking place.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Exceptional care
body: My husband has a number of chronic health conditions and spent 12 days in King George Hospital in January after an emergency admittance when a further problem was identified. Since then his health has been monitored carefully including using the e reporting system which has worked well. 2 weeks ago blood tests were ordered as part of an investigation. These results triggered more urgent blood tests and those results were immediately acted upon. Queen's  A & E  were contacted, my husband received a phone call, I collected a letter with all the relevant information and my husband was admitted within 4 hours of arriving at A & E. The care and consideration shown to my husband could not have been greater. Even the blood test were taken at home! Thank you.

title: Great Hospital
body: Absolutely fantastic staff. Was checked on all the time asking if I needed anything. Staff are so friendly and caring.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent care in challenging times
body: My son was admitted early hours this morning with suspected appendicitis. The warmth, care and reassurance that was offered was excellent. All the staff were so friendly and put us as ease. Such a lovely team of people.

title: Fast response
body: Completed an eConsult form for multiple painful limbs and I had a very quick response with a way ahead mapped out.

title: Great maternity care
body: Went in for my 12 week ultrasound scan last month. When the combined scan and blood test results showed a higher risk for Down’s syndrome than normal I was immediately taken to a side room and given the chance to call my husband in (he was not with me due to COVID) before we discussed next steps. About three different people talked us clearly through the issue, as well as the risks and options we had open to us. We went for a CVS test and had it carried out within a couple of hours, the doctor was great and results were given to us within the next couple of days. I’ve been on pregnancy apps and people have had to wait weeks for those results in the US, despite the extortionate prices they’re paying for healthcare. We were also offered food and drink even though we were only there for a few hours, and everyone was lovely. Really reassuring experience for a first time mum.

title: Excellent Practice
body:
Find the staff and doctors at this practice listen and meet your needs. Very caring. Working hard under COVID 19

Overall excellent service

author: Golden Slumber
title: Total absence of crisis team since COVID-19
body:
I have a bi polar diagnosis. I am usually seen bt a psychiatrist, a CPN ( nurse) and have monthly injections of my MH medication.  
In this Trust we are told got to A&E when in crisis and we have 3 A&E. The crisis teams are across the 2 council areas that make up this Trust. For 10 yrs they have not increased the staff from one worker only per borough on duty. Not a single professional in this MH Trust seems to think that 2 workers for a population of half million residents a problem. Even when they tut and shake their heads and say that's awful when pts tell them how poor The crisis team or line in before coronavirus.  
The management here actually justify the appalling treatment of people in crisis by using this ratio as an excuse. God knows what the CCGs who fund have been doing all this time, maybe someone should ask why mentally ill pts aren't getting emergency access to treatment. I don't care about the words MH workers use saying a crisis and an emergency are different - No they are not if you are the person about to jump off a bridge or in front of a truck!Once COVID-19 came it got so much worse- it was like they forgot they are actually emergency NHS and just like in physical healthcare expected to see pts. I went to 2 of the 3 A&E's in March before official lockdown on 23rd. Except the A&Es by then were already turning away MH pts unless had taken overdose.But at the same time there was NO place to be seen in crisis. None. Not until weeks later when a hub was opened in the psych hospital grounds and then twice I was screamed at for going there without ringing ahead, when the A&E had told me to. Who on earth in a MH trust thinks someone in a life-threatening situation should have to call what is always an answerphone to get life-saving treatment?On 5 separate incidents in March alone, I was getting more and more suicidal. I was agitated, not sleeping at all, they knew I had attempted suicide before and ended up in ICU. I am under the Care of the MH Trust but the community team completely shut down at same time. No letters about what to do, no appts, no duty line as ALWAYS engaged or to answerphone or sometimes just diverted into the void.ALL GPs had shut down and because the MH Trust had not updated my GP re: medication it was stopped dead, which is probably why I was getting so unwell. The clinic i am meant to go to in my mh team just shut its doors so my injections stopped and no gp so no one to chase it.  
4 times my friend rang the crisis line and was told there was NO crisis team because of the virus. And the crisis houses told me they were only taking patients from the wards. It took 3 weeks for the hub place to see me then they sent me to Whittington hospital because I had by now taken too much of an old medication because I couldn't get mine and A&E there sent me back. The crisis team at the hub told me to go away because they don't deal with overdoses and so in one night I ended up there twice and 2 different A&E. Everybody said go away even when I told them I was suicidal had missed injections now twice.  
Still now they are not working. I was sectioned by police in another part of London and spent 3 days in a different MH Trust. This one said they had no beds so I was discharged and still no follow up. In the end police and ambulance kept coming to my home because I was at risk and they could not take me anywhere either as nowhere would take a MH patient who needed medical care as well . I needed blood tests and also had a cough but I didn't think it was coronavirus because I have asthma. I don't know if these are real nurses in the crisis team and they said they had no doctors when I went but who knows if that was true. It is a mess in mental health and they STILL not giving appts when I know others who have appts for routine physical care in the same hospitals and elsewhere.  
My GP says she hasnt heard from the MH Trust and has contacted them again and again. I can't be supported on the phone when very unwell like many many mental health patients. I have friends who don't even have phones and have been sectioned because this. Trust staff didn't make face to face appointments for people who couldn't do phone ones. The GP says the NHS told MH Trusts to make sure they saw pts and they didn't. In the end my GP had to do some special arrangements and send me to a different place to get my depot injections. I think this Trust is a very dangerous place and wonder what sort of doctors and nurses behave like this? I felt that they were so aggressive, even the police and ambulance seemed to agree and were arguing with them and said it was a real problem they couldn't take anyone for mental health safety. It is their job so what have they been doing this whole time and WHY STILL no appointments face to face?

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Camden and Islington NHS Foundation Trust

author: Riggers123
title: How an Operation Changed my Sons Life
body:
My son had to have an operation to lengthen is upper jaw and reduce his lower jaw ( I believe it is called maxillary osteotomy and mandibular osteotomy)  
This happened a couple of years ago but I felt compelled to write due to the fact it has changed his whole life  
It has brought about a totally changed person in my son and given myself and my wife great peace of mind  
He was bullied at school and college due to his looks and once came home saying he wanted to die, the verbal and physical anguish he faced on a daily basis was horrendous to hear and my wife and I worried constantly especially about his mental health  
He was the first thing I thought about every morning and the last thing I thought about before going to sleep  
To see my son so upset every day took a toll on him and us as a family, he had no self confidence, no self worth and constant held his hand over his jaw as people would stare  
After the operation I showed him a picture of his new face as he lay in the hospital bed and he broke down and cried he was so happy, in fact we all cried.  
I can never thank Mr Panesar his orthodontist and Mr Williams his surgeon enough they were not only exceptional at their jobs but they always had time for the questions this father had  
They turned his life round and I can finally sleep at night  
The care he received was exemplary and I could not ask for anything better from all involved  
An absolutely massive thank you

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: EMJAYKAY
title: Systemic Refusal to any post Traumatic Brain Injury care.
body:
My issues have been going on for 36 years, however, the last 3 in particular, now that I'm fully aware of the root cause and condition of my health issue, my experience has been Kafkaesque at best.  
In 1984 as a teenager I sustained a Traumatic Brain Injury after falling into an uncovered streetworks excavation on a dark night, while returning home from an errand. The result was an operation to treat an Extradural Haematoma 48 hours later, having spent this time deteriorating in an A&E ward. Physically on the surface I appeared to have made a fully recovery, however, I experienced severe fatigue, headaches and sensory issues. My concentration was poor, as was my ability to retain new information. Not ideal for a teenager about to start university. After approaching my GP with my parents, I was accused of malingering and my parents were informed that all that was required was that I needed a "good shake".  
Roll forward a few years after having failed university and mental health problems have came into my life in addition to the aforementioned sequelae. At every juncture with mental health services I asked if the roots of my problem lay with the TBI. At every juncture I was given a diagnosis from psychosis to GAD, OCD, or depression.  
Roll forward to 2016 and I'm about to commence my third stay in as many years at a private sector psychiatric hospital after yet another breakdown and a head full of suicidal ideation. At this point the consultant psychiatrist decided to consider that there may be an organic root to my decades long mental health issues which had been, despite my best efforts, remaining unresolved. Again the TBI wasn't considered, this time it was the possibility of an ASD. One year after obtaining a GP referreral to Autism Scotland my name came up on the list for an assessment, which I had in March 2017. The Psychology team at Autism Scotland concluded that I did not meet the criteria for an ASD diagnosis, however it appeared I was suffering from issues in my pre-frontal cortex as a result of my TBI. This was confirmed in August 2017 by a private sector Clinical Psychologist with decades of experience in the field of Brain Injury.  
At his suggestion my wife approached NHS Lanarkshire for assistance, only to be refused. No other mental health support was forthcoming and after yet another episode of a breakdown and suicidal ideation I spent October 2017 in a private sector Psychiatric Hospital.  
I began seeing the private sector Clinical Psychologist in January 2018 and began identifying the myriad of issues that a person faces after a TBI; the headaches; the concentration; the memory problems; the challenges to my executive function; emotional dysregulation and lability; speech issues and the FATIGUE!-my nemesis; every day is a lottery as to whether I will have enough energy to carry out the basic functions that comprise my eroded daily life. The Clinical Psychologist made it clear that additional support would be required from the NHS if I was to gain a daily existence that bore any resemblance to 'normal daily daily living'. None of this was forthcoming. I subsequently spent February 2019 again back in a private sector Psychiatric Hospital with exactly the same mental health issues and by that time we had moved home to the NHS Forth Valley area.  
Since first having my long standing suspicions that my health issues were related to my TBI confirmed in 2017, my wife and I have carried out extensive research both online (and there are many peer reviewed scientific and medical papers on the subject) and with the help of the Headway Scotland charity. There is a great deal of easily accessible information out there. It begs the question; why has nobody I have encountered in the health profession with the exception of a Professor at Autism Scotland and the private sector Clinical Psychologist I have been attending been privvy to this extensive information?  
In August 2019, in a moment of utter despair, I swallowed every tablet I have in the desperate hope of ending my pain and sheer trauma. I was taken to A&E and when it was established that I had not taken enough tablets to ensure the lethality I so desperately sought, I was discharged. On visiting my GP a few days later I was referred to Forth Valley mental health services. Two months later after some further calls from my GP, I received my first home visit from two Occupational Therapists. During this visit, I gave my account of the last 35 years of living with a TBI. A few days later I received a letter with what looked like a Christmas list; I would receive OT input in order to help me with my now defunct daily living skills; I would undergo a CT scan to assess my neurological health; I would receive a full Neuro-Psychological assessment; and I would be appointed a Psychiatrist.  
Thus far, bearing in mind that the letter I received was in October 2019, the following commitments have been fulfilled:  
1. I have received 3 visits from an OT.  
2. I have had a CT scan in November 2019 however, the results have never been discussed with me other than the brief comment "your brain injury is quite obvious on the CT scan".  
3. I have had one Psychiatric appointment in November 2019 where the problem with my current medication; I have been on since its prescription at the private sector Psychiatric Hospital in October 2017 was discussed owing to its lack of SMC approval. No other issues were discussed other than that I would undergo regular Psychiatric appointments by March 2020 at the very latest. This medication has allowed me a full nights sleep after more than 30 years of chronic insomnia. I have been found wanting after 30 years of a BNF full of a myriad of pschotropic medication; from the chemical cosh of Chlorpromazine in the 90's, to Tricyclics, to SSRIs of every flavour. I currently pay privately for my medication at great expense over and above the private sector psychiatric and psychological treatments I have had since 2012.  
In conclusion, has my experience been;  
1. Good? ...At no point has it been less than traumatic.  
2. What could have been better? ... Everything, or perhaps my parents should have eschewed the Brain Operation in 1984 and allowed me to die.  
3. How do I feel about my care? ...What care? At what point will anyone care? Personally, I feel my next point of contact with NHS Scotland will be to become nothing other than an entry in the book of statistics documenting yet another figure in the leading cause of death for men of my age.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Excellent service
body: As someone who works in a hospital it is always daunting to be on the other side. Everyone I encountered today was professional and friendly. The security at the door who re-directed me, the man at reception who made sure I was Covid safe and then escorted me to the clinic. I had to attend elm ward for investigation after I found a lump in my breast. The patient flow was excellent, everyone introduced themselves and I felt completely at ease. To the HCAs, clinic clerk, nurses, radiographer, drs, thank you, you have an excellent service. I got the all clear and I left feeling that I had been fully investigated and my concerns taken seriously. Great work.

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust

title: lovely staff
body: all clinicians as well as admin staff are so kind and caring. very helpful and overall is a great surgery

title: Great experience
body: Really lovely staff. I came in for my daughters immunisations and got seen straight away. Really recommend to everyone

title: Well managed!
body: I had maxfax surgery in July and was an inpatient on the japonica ward. Couldn't fault the "covid controls" in place everywhere from the green zone door, to the ward, to leaving again the next day. Everyone I came into contact with tried to keep me at ease and calm. It's not easy having surgery when there can't be anyone with you, but all the nurses and doctors I saw were all so friendly that it wasn't so bad. A massive thank you and well done to everyone in pre op assessment, covid testing, japonica ward, operating theatres, and everyone else for managing so well during covid-19 and keeping patients calm and safe

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust

author: Ashes87
title: Memories made
body: Our little girl recieved excellent care in Newcastle Freeman hospital. She recieved a cardiac transplantation in April 2019. She was 2 years old at the time. The team work tirelessly to ensure she was well looked after throughout. They had a person for everything and were very well organised. Daily ward rounds to nurses making sure not only our little girls was ok but we were. Being from the north west area we were put up by CHUF in scott house so the worry and stress of were to stay was taken away. Brilliant doctors, nurses, consultant, surgeons, play therapist, dietitians the list is endless of the people and support systems they have in place. Our story sadly didn't end well and we lost our gorgeous girl but we are so proud of her and her fight and also the people who helped us through them dark moments while in hospital. Even after her death they still phone to check on us. Our hearts will never heal but we know that she was taken care of in the best place and they did everything humanly possible to keep her with us. Thank you will never be enough for giving our girl an extra 4 months with us. Memories made.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Fairtricket
title: Home respiratory nurse
body:
My stepmum was admitted to Aberdeen Royal infirmary a week past Sunday and she was discharged on the Thursday with a home non-invasive ventilation kit to help her with her Type II respiratory failure.  
She wasn’t very sure how to use the equipment and as a family we struggled over that weekend to support her to use it. We have since made contact with Trish, the home respiratory service lead nurse. Trish is amazing. Her patience and commitment to her job is commendable. She is supporting us daily to work with mum to help use the system.  
She has listened to our woes and has offered us comfort and excellent advice. If you have an award scheme for staff who go above and beyond the job then I would like to nominate Trish. If you could see yourselves to invest more into the service to offer seven day funded support then we think this would be money well spent.

author: john do
title: Car parking at the Vic'
body:
I attend the Victoria three times per week, every week. The car parking at the front main entrance is terrible! Many people park in the drop off area ALL DAY. Others sit in their car while parked in disabled only bays- most don't even have a blue badge.  
The blue badge holders don't seem to realise it is NOT permitted to sit in the car in a disabled parking spot while waiting for another person. Disabled parking is for PARKING, NOT WAITING!  
The hospital is full of security staff, it would be good if they occasionally patrolled the parking areas at the front door.
